title: What Beatles songs did Ringo sing? - Quora

response.answer_text: In chronological order: (year and name of the album - UK canon - in brackets) Boys (1963 - “Please Please Me”)I Wanna Be Your Man (1963 - “With the Beatles”)Matchbox (1964 - “Past Masters”, “Rarities”/”Long Tall Sally” EP)Honey Don’t (1964 - “Beatles For Sale”)Act Naturally (1965 - “Help!”)What Goes On (1965 - “Rubber Soul”)Yellow Submarine (1966 - “Revolver”, plus the OST)With A Little Help From My Friends (1967 - “Sgt. Pepper’s…”)Goodnight (1968 - “The White Album”)Don’t Pass Me By (1968 -”The White Album”)Octopus’s Garden (1969 - “Abbey Road”)Eleven on the whole. He was the sole songwriter in two (numbers 10 and 11). Four were covers (nrs. 1, 3, 4, 5). He had nearly one song per album, on average (no song in “A Hard Day’s Night” , “Magical Mystery Tour” and “Let It Be” issues) - two, only at the “White Album”. For a more comprehensive answer, which was used as source for this one, I strongly suggest to have a look at: Top 10 Ringo Starr Beatles Songs. Thank you.

Boys: The Shirelles cover. Awesome band performance, actually, one of my favorite Harrison guitar solos. He does two of them. (Guitar solos, not Shirelles.)I Want To Be Your Man. (John and Paul kind of take over for the chorus. Underrated song because it is relatively simple bundle of cliches but that is not always bad.)Matchbox. It’s a song about a matchbox holding his clothes, messin’ ’round his tree, getting his peaches and him being a little dog til your big dog comes, at which point she watches her puppy-dog run.Honey, Don’t. Aww, rock on, George, one time for Ringo.Act Naturally. From Help! Well-done but still mehsville.What Goes On. Country-rock; nice harmonies and guitar solo: what Act Naturally should have been. Has co-writing credit.Yellow Submarine. An eerie Edgar Allen Poe-style story of a sea-faring man, born in Liverpool, who has an epiphany he is compelled to share with everyone, all of us, through Ringo: We all in fact, in actuality, live in a Yellow Submarine. Ringo proclaims that “Every One of Us Has all We Need”, a clear prophecy of a future in which the Communist Utopia has come to pass, and “The Band Begins to Play”, an image that evokes the horrors of a genocidal 20th century.The Beatles were the first band to do Edgar Allen Poe/Marxist/genocide stories: this fact is inarguable.With a Little Help from My Friends. He gets high with a little help from his friends. Ooh, the subversity of it all. A companion to Lou Reed’s 67 classic “Heroin."He probably sings co-lead on Flying.Don’t Pass Me By. Country rock. Boring unless you are stoned. Sounds like he is playing the drums with a sledgehammer, which is cool. Stereo and mono mix differences in violin bit.Good Night. As lush as "Long and Winding Road”, only Paul doesn’t bitch about it.Octopus’s Garden. Totally sexual; obviously a song about going “under the sea”, if you know what I mean. Features backing vocals by trippy, strobe-lit chipmunks.Carry That Weight: co-lead with George and Paul.“Shout!”from Anthology 1. (co-lead: a little bit LOUDER now!)“If You’ve Got Trouble” from Anthology 2. A true piece of shit with good drumming and a biting guitar solo.
